org.zoolu.util

Class BitString

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.zoolu.util.BitString

  • public class BitString
extends java.lang.Object
    String of bits (0 or 1).

    A BitString object is constant in length (not in value). That means that the length can not be changed after it is created, while the bit string value can be changed through the methods setBit(boolean,int) and setBits(BitString,int)

    For variable-length bit strings you can use BitStringBuffer objects.

                 int off,

      • BitString

        public BitString(byte[] buf,
                 boolean low_first)
        Creates a new BitString from bits within an array of bytes.
        Parameters:
        buf - the buffer containing the bit string
        low_first - true if, within each byte, the bit with the lowest value must be taken first; false in the opposite case (i.e. bit with the greatest value must be taken first)

      • BitString

        public BitString(byte[] buf,
                 int off,
                 int len,
                 boolean low_first)
        Creates a new BitString from bits within an array of bytes.
        Parameters:
        buf - the buffer containing the bit string
        off - the offset of the first byte within the buffer
        len - the total number of bytes
        low_first - true if, within each byte, the bit with the lowest value must be taken first; false in the opposite case (i.e. bit with the greatest value must be taken first)

      • substring

        public BitString substring(int begin)
        Returns a new string that is a substring of this string. The substring begins with the bit at the specified index begin and extends to the end of this string.

      • substring

        public BitString substring(int begin,
                           int end)
        Returns a new string that is a substring of this string. The substring begins at the specified index begin and extends to the bit at index end - 1. Thus the length of the substring is end-begin.

      • startsWith

        public boolean startsWith(BitString prefix)
        Tests if this string starts with the specified prefix.
        Parameters:
        prefix - the prefix
        Returns:
        true if the sequence represented by the argument is a prefix of this string; false otherwise. Note also that true will be returned if the argument is an empty string or is equal to this string

      • startsWith

        public boolean startsWith(BitString prefix,
                          int offset)
        Tests if the substring of this string beginning at the specified offset starts with the specified prefix.
        Parameters:
        prefix - the prefix
        offset - where to begin looking in this string
        Returns:
        true if the sequence represented by the argument is a prefix of the substring of this object starting at index toffset; false otherwise. The result is false if toffset is negative or greater than the length of this string

      • setBit

        public void setBit(boolean bit,

        Sets the i bit.
        Parameters:
        bit - the new bit value (true=1, false=0)
        i - the index of the bit to be set

        public void setBits(BitString substring,

        Parameters:
        substring - the substring that replaces bits starting from offset
        offset - the offset from which to start the replacement

      • getBytes

        public byte[] getBytes(boolean low_first)
        Gets bytes. Gets an array of bytes containing the BitString.
        Parameters:
        low_first - true if, within each byte, the bit with the lowest value must be taken first; false in the opposite case (i.e. bit with the greatest value must be taken first)
        Returns:
        the array of bytes containing the BitString

      • getBytes

        public int getBytes(byte[] buf,
                    int off,
                    boolean low_first)
        Gets bytes. Gets an array of bytes containing the BitString.
        Parameters:
        buf - the buffer where the BitString bytes are written
        off - the offset within the buffer
        low_first - true if, within each byte, the bit with the lowest value must be taken first; false in the opposite case (i.e. bit with the greatest value must be taken first)
        Returns:
        the number of bytes

        Returns:
